isis.stitle: DT 466 / DT 570 / HT 570 Service Manual - 2004 Emissions with EGR - Front Cover and Related Components - Checking Gear Train Timing Without Removing Front Cover - DT 466 Engines Only

svcsubproc.title: Method One - Using a Feeler Gauge

step1.para: Rotate the engine to approximately TDC (Top Dead Center) compression on No. 1 cylinder (no valves open). Set the lash on the No. 1 intake valve to the nominal lash setting of 0.48 mm (0.019 in).
Scribe a mark on the damper pulley at a radial distance of 82.5 mm (3.25 in) or a straight line distance of 81 mm (3.188 in) clockwise from the timing notch as viewed from the front of the engine.

Place a 0.28 mm (0.011 in) feeler gauge between the rocker arm and the valve bridge of the No. 1 intake valve. Slowly rotate the engine forward (clockwise) until the intake valve starts to lift and the feeler gauge becomes tight. The mark should line up with the TDC arrow on the front cover or be within 3.5 crankshaft degrees of it. 3.5 degrees is equivalent to a radial (or straight) line distance of 6.8 mm (0.27 in) at the damper pulley.

note.para: One tooth "out of time" on the gear train equals approximately 11 degrees of movement or 21.4 mm (27/32 in) of radial distance of damper pulley.

step1.para: If the timing on the No.1 valve is within specifications, the other valves, barring extreme camshaft lobe wear or poor adjustment, will also be in time. If timing is found to be incorrect, removal of the front cover is required to inspect the punch marks on the gear train.

svcsubproc.title: Method Two - Using a Dial Indicator

step1.para: Adjust the No.1 intake valve with the No.1 piston set at TDC (Top Dead Center) compression stroke to 0.48 mm (0.019 in). Install a 0.28 mm (0.011 in) feeler gauge between the rocker arm and the valve bridge of the No.1 intake valve.
Position the magnetic base dial indicator on the valve cover fence of the cylinder head rail with the indicator tip on the No.1 intake rocker arm tip.
Rotate the engine approximately one full revolution in either direction to a position 360 degrees from starting point.
The dial indicator should read within the range of 0.13-0.25 mm (0.005-0.010 in) from the starting position for proper gear train timing.
If dial indicator readings are found to be outside of this range, removal of the front cover is required to inspect the punch marks on the gear train.
